history.content: For myself, I've noticed that even when problems ask for a formal solution, intuition is exceptional at pointing me in the right direction. Posting non-anon because lol @2944 -------- My response to this varies on which courses you've taken / felt were too procedural in the problems. If you're primarily referring to lower-divs, then sure: easier / intro courses tend to be more computational / procedural, and not require much intuition (something that technical courses often have a problem with). But as you move into upper division / grad courses, then intuition is quite important. My usual example of when I've personally found intuition to be extremely important is coming up with dynamic programming algorithms. I first tried to learn DP in sophomore year of high school, after I discovered that DP was extremely useful in programming contests, e.g. at the high school level, most of the hardest questions in programming contests were DP-based. However, I just could not understand DP; I could learn individual DP algorithms, but I didn't get it to be able to apply the idea to new problems, despite spending quite a bit of time over the next few years trying to understand it. Then, one day (in my freshman year in college), I looked at a problem, and said: "oh, this is just straightforward DP"; looked back at some other problems, and realized that I had just suddenly accumulated enough background experience (i.e. intuition) to do DP problems (at least, the straightforward ones). Talking to other 170 TAs, others have had the same experience I did: DP was super-hard, until they "got" it, at which point it became super-easy. Other usage of intuition: if you know the formula to solve a problem, great. But what if you don't know the formula? Intuition allows you to be confident about guessing what the formula is. I have, on multiple occasions in exams, thought something like: "I don't know what X is, but I'm going to assume it's the 'obvious' thing, and answer the question that way"; intuition is what allows me to consider it "obvious". I know someone who has complained about getting an A on the CS188 exams (which generally have a reputation for being hard) because he didn't actually know the material but could intuitively guess all the answers.

For myself, I've noticed that even when problems ask for a formal solution, intuition is exceptional at pointing me in the right direction.

Posting non-anon because lol @2944
--------
My response to this varies on which courses you've taken / felt were too procedural in the problems. If you're primarily referring to lower-divs, then sure: easier / intro courses tend to be more computational / procedural, and not require much intuition (something that technical courses often have a problem with). But as you move into upper division / grad courses, then intuition is quite important.
My usual example of when I've personally found intuition to be extremely important is coming up with dynamic programming algorithms. I first tried to learn DP in sophomore year of high school, after I discovered that DP was extremely useful in programming contests, e.g. at the high school level, most of the hardest questions in programming contests were DP-based. However, I just could not understand DP; I could learn individual DP algorithms, but I didn't get it to be able to apply the idea to new problems, despite spending quite a bit of time over the next few years trying to understand it. Then, one day (in my freshman year in college), I looked at a problem, and said: "oh, this is just straightforward DP"; looked back at some other problems, and realized that I had just suddenly accumulated enough background experience (i.e. intuition) to do DP problems (at least, the straightforward ones). Talking to other 170 TAs, others have had the same experience I did: DP was super-hard, until they "got" it, at which point it became super-easy.
Other usage of intuition: if you know the formula to solve a problem, great. But what if you don't know the formula?
Intuition allows you to be confident about guessing what the formula is. I have, on multiple occasions in exams, thought something like: "I don't know what X is, but I'm going to assume it's the 'obvious' thing, and answer the question that way"; intuition is what allows me to consider it "obvious".
I know someone who has complained about getting an A on the CS188 exams (which generally have a reputation for being hard) because he didn't actually know the material but could intuitively guess all the answers.

For myself, I've noticed that even when problems ask for a formal solution, intuition is exceptional at pointing me in the right direction.

Posting non-anon because lol @2944

children.subject: It's tough to say - I've only taken CS 70 here, but intuition legit carried me through that class
I heard you got an A+ Richard. Congrats!
Where did you get that from lol, thanks though
We're mutual friends. We know each other (not too well though). My friend told me
Ah... I can guess at your identity then ;)
Wait so you didn't get an A+?
You were a role model for me for a few days...

Yeppers, I know who you are. Thanks ^_^ 

I did not deny that I got an A+. I merely wish to avoid the appearance of bragging

Not the anon above but just to clarify 

Did you get an A+ or not?
Dude Richard, I have never met you and have no idea who you are. I was just joking around about you getting an A+ and being mutual friends. Thanks for letting me know though.
According to google translate that means, Jesus Bit** Fu**
Richard what class do you have the strongest intuition in? Mine is linalg.

I think of intuition as that Aha! moment that points you to where you wanna go - and the more you notice things and see patterns and try/learn new approaches and new ways of conceptualizing (i.e. the more you build intuition), the easier it gets to solve problems and the more interesting it gets to solve harder problems.

The biggest thing for me is that intuition can be built - you aren't just born with some level of logical prowess that stays the same forever; the more logical/mathematical thinking you do, the more and more you grasp tricky concepts and solve tricky problems. It's along the lines of mathematical maturity, I suppose.

No, he got As, despite not studying. He felt that this meant the exam was poorly designed, and that he deserved a lower grade based on his effort. (I disagreed, since he only thought it was easy because of his intuition, but w/e.)

"

I know someone who has complained about getting an A on the CS188 exams (which generally have a reputation for being hard) because he didn't actually know the material but could intuitively guess all the answers."
So he had intuition but wasn't getting A's?

history.content: All my Professors and TAs talk about intuition but frankly, I don't see the purpose. 99% of the time, you're not using intuition, you're just using a formula or following a certain set of steps to solve a problem. You don't need to keep intuiting the problem. Worst case, you can always re-implement the formula if you don't understand it.
history.subject: Is intuition overrated?
